poem:
"Ode to a Reminder"

In the morning paper,  
Rushdie, scribe with 
one eye blinded,
speaks of free speech, a 
valuable bloom in danger
of wilting.

Warnings to the youth,
as the taste of another
Trump reign broods —
dark like winter fruit.

Words are our keepsakes,
he cautions,
We must not let them slip 
away,
for they are 
our robust red wheelbarrows,
glazed with dew,
in the mornings of our days.
